comments.author: Sigrid Jensen

comments.text:
+Rose K remission is not even the right word unfortunately. It is not like 
cancer.  It truly CAN be controlled with diet/exercise and sometimes the 
addition of Type 2 medications and insulin. But let's be clear. Insulin is 
NOT a drug. We all (well, not me) have it inour bodies.  T1D is totally 
deficient. T2D is inadequate or insufficient.

It depends. If you have a diabetes pump, then you don't have to take shots 
every day. But yes. I remember the days of the insulin pen. Even still 
sometimes when my pump isn't working, I'll just take a vile of insulin 
(there I go making up words) and some needles. I'll the usually take the 
shot in like a restaurant bathroom or something. I took my first shot in 
the hospital when I was first diagnosed. The nurse said most kid will wait 
years before they take their first shot on their own. Idk if that was true 
or if she was just saying that. But at the time I believed it. :)
comments.author: William Gentry

comments.text:

I'm glad i don't have diabetes. I HATE shots. and needles
comments.author: AR osen on AJ

comments.text:
+Rose K Once again, this is not correct information. Neither type of 
diabetes is reversible! Type 2 diabetes can be controlled, but never 
reversed. The most common misunderstanding of type 2 diabetes is that if a 
person never eats any sweets/sugar/carbs that they will be "cured". That is 
not the case! In a non-diabetic person food is turned into glucose, 
delivered along with insulin to the cells, the insulin unlocks the door and 
the glucose delivers the energy, etc. for the cells to work properly. Type 
1 diabetics' bodies do no produce the insulin, so the cells aren't unlocked 
at all. Type 2 diabetics' bodies produce insulin, but their cells don't 
recognize the insulin properly so the cells may or may not unlock. Over 
time, Type 2 diabetics might find their body no longer produces insulin or 
enough insulin and they require shots/pump. 

Personally, I am thrilled that more research is currently happening 
regarding type 2 diabetes and our food sources. Check out fedupmovie.com
comments.author: KGaver617

comments.text:
Type 1s (like in this video) need to take one shot daily in addition to one 
with every meal. So anywhere from 3-6 daily. Some people use a pump 
instead, which is continuously pumping insulin inside you - that has to be 
replaced every 2-3 days.
comments.author: Everett Snieder

comments.author: Anders Omel

comments.text:
It depends on the type! There's type 1 diabetes and then there's type 2. 
Here's a definition of both that I found on Mayo Clinic: Type 1 diabetes, 
once known as juvenile diabetes or insulin-dependent diabetes, is a chronic 
condition in which the pancreas produces little or no insulin, a hormone 
needed to allow sugar (glucose) to enter cells to produce energy. The far 
more common type 2 diabetes occurs when the body becomes resistant to 
insulin or doesn't make enough insulin.

I think it depends on how extreme the case is that determines if you need 
to take insulin, but don't quote me on that. I'm unsure.
comments.author: Anders Omel

comments.text:
+Rose K  you are perpetuating more myths about diabetes. Please read up 
from CREDIBLE medical sites.

Type 1 diabetes is often diagnosed in younger people, but can be diagnosed 
at any age. Type 1 is when the body does not produce insulin. Type 2 
diabetes is not caused by people being older or overweight. Type 2 diabetes 
is insulin resistance where your body does not recognize the insulin 
required to open your cells and accept the fuel.

By the way, while many people with type 2 diabetes are overweight, recent 
research is showing that is a symptom of diabetes and not the cause.

comments.text:
Studies have also found that those most at risk of contracting( not sure if 
I used correct terminology) are those who inhabit regions far north/ south 
of the equator. Someone in Norway has a 300 times chance of getting type 1 
as opposed to someone in Guatemala. It's also most common in the Northern 
European countries(Norway, Denmark, U.K., Finland) it's probably due to 
lack of sufficient vitamin d. So if you don't want to get it don't be 
Scandinavian, don't live at the 45 parallel.
comments.author: Black flames31

comments.author: The Gaming Cat

comments.text:
+whatever1210 Some fact checking is in order I think. Type 2 diabetes is 
caused from a resistance to produced insulin in the body. The body produces 
more and more insulin to compensate for the resistance. This also why 
obesity is now thought to be a complication from type 2 diabetes and not 
the other way around. Insulin being a growth hormone just keeps adding the 
pounds on as the pancreas kicks out more and more of it; and being 
overweight means you need more insulin to feed those extra cells with 
energy, it's a circular problem. 

It's the exact reason why drugs such as Metformin and an increase in 
exercise work with type 2 diabetics, they have the insulin already 
available but they are not using it effectively anymore. Hypoglycemia won't 
occur even if you have a ton of insulin in your blood unless it's able to 
do it's job. 

I have many family members with Type 2 Diabetes, and I myself am Type 1. 
I'm well versed on the two diseases.
comments.author: Hank Devos

comments.text:
Hank, it's not that type 2 have too much it's that it doesn't quite work as 
well as it could too much insulin is hypoglycemia which is complete 
opposite of diabetes. I love the medical side of YouTube haha. :)
comments.author: whatever1210

comments.text:
Well not quite. You cannot get rid of type 2 diabetes either. And there is 
a large amount of research on what the actual root cause of type 2 is. But 
they are indeed different animals; type 1 is an auto immune disease while 
type is a metabolic disease, they end up having the same complications and 
outcomes though because of their affect on insulin production (too much in 
type 2 and none at all in type 1). Type 2 can also be controlled via 
exercise (to an extent) while type 1 cannot.
comments.author: Hank Devos

top_comment.text:
For those of you who don't know, insulin is a vital protein created by your 
pancreas; insulin helps in breaking down carbohydrates(sugars) in your 
bloodstream. Having a pancreas that is incapable of creating insulin is *purely 
genetic*.
Diabetics(people who's bodies can't create insulin) *need* insulin shots in 
order to *live*. Without it, they'll die.﻿
top_comment.author: Enoch Meyer

comments.text:
+Jeffrey Chumley yeah you are correct I forgot that. whoops haha. you'd 
think after 25 years I'd be good with knowing this stuff, but I don't know 
everything. I just know don't eat chocolate when low it ends up biting you 
in the end.
comments.author: whatever1210

comments.text: +Jeffrey Chumley Thanks for educating us.:)
comments.author: Enoch Meyer

comments.text:
+whatever1210 Insulin is both a protein and a hormone. The word protein is 
a description of a molecule's chemical makeup, while the word hormone 
describes the function of a molecule (in this case, long-distance chemical 
signaling, often involving transportation through the bloodstream). 
Hormones can be either proteins or steroids. Also, neither Type I or Type 
II diabetes is purely genetic; there are other factors involved. However, 
that doesn't change the fact that people with Type I diabetes (and some 
with Type II) require insulin to prevent serious complications that can 
culminate in death. Not meaning to sound pompous, I just happen to be a 
scientist that performs endocrinology testing and some diabetes diagnostic 
testing.
comments.author: Jeffrey Chumley

comments.text: Whatever.
comments.author: Enoch Meyer

top_comment.text:
Just to point out, the appendix isn't a useless organ, in fact very useful, 
it is a place in which the intestines good bacteria can be stored, in the 
situation where someone gets an infection, the good bacteria can move to 
the appendix to be stored until the bad bacteria is flushed from the body's 
system, in the instance however that the appendix receives bad bacteria as 
mentioned then it is at risk to infection, and can rupture, tho we can live 
without the appendix is is still in fact a very useful organ in the body, I 
like to use the example we can still live without an eye or an arm or a 
leg, doesn't mean we don't need it. ﻿

comments.author: Celeste M.

comments.text: Studio C did a great job with the sketch!
comments.author: Branden Draper

captions.text:
>>FIRST OF ALL, MATT, WE WANT YOU TO KNOW
THAT
WE ARE ALL YOUR FRIENDS HERE.
>>NO MATT. WE FOUND THIS IN YOUR CAR.

>>SO, YOU'RE NOT EVEN GOING TO PRETEND IT'S
NOT YOURS?
>>I ASSUMED THAT WHEN YOU SAID YOU OPENED IT.
>>HOW LONG HAS THIS BEEN GOING ON?
GUYS DIDN'T KNOW THIS, BUT I HAVE DIABETES.
>>MATT, WE CAN'T HAVE A SERIOUS CONVERSATION IF YOU'RE JUST
YOU'RE AT SOME PARTY AND THE GUYS ARE
AND YOU JUST CAN'T SAY NO.
>>WE'RE GOING TO HELP YOU GET THROUGH THIS MATT.
>>I KNOW IT FEELS THAT WAY NOW, BUT YOU DON'T NEED
I JUST NEED IT TO LIVE.
>>THERE ARE OTHER WAYS TO FEEL ALIVE!
YOU CAN GET A NATURAL HIGHS.
HERE, HAVE THIS GIANT PIXIE STICK.
DO YOU NOT UNDERSTAND HOW DIABETES WORKS?

I NEED INSULIN TO REGULATE MY BLOOD SUGAR
LEVEL.
LIKE RIGHT NOW, I HAD A LOT OF CARBS AT LUNCH,
SO I NEED TO TAKE SOME INSULIN TO BREAK DOWN THE
SUGARS OTHERWISE BAD THINGS WILL START TO HAPPEN TO ME.
>>LOOK MATT. I KNOW THAT YOU'RE PROBABLY
BUT YOU'RE GOING TO QUIT RIGHT NOW.
I'M GOING TO GO INTO KETOACIDOSIS.
WE'RE GOING TO STAY RIGHT HERE TO MAKE SURE YOU
>>SO THAT'S WHAT THEY'RE CALLING THEM THESE DAYS.
>>LOOK, IN A VERY REMOVED WAY I AM
BUT, IN A MORE IMPORTANT AND LIFE THREATENING WAY,
I AM VERY UPSET WITH YOU GUYS.
YOU'RE COMPLETELY IGNORANT ABOUT A VERY PREVALENT DISEASE.
>>WAIT, WHO ARE YOU TRYING TO CALL?

ARE YOU TRYING TO SCORE SOME INSULIN FROM
YOUR PHARMACIST?
BECAUSE I'M GOING TO NEED ONE SOON.
THE PANCREAS IS A USELESS ORGAN.

>>NO, THE APPENDIX IS THE THING AT THE BACK
OF TEXTBOOKS.
>>OKAY LISTEN, WE UNDERSTAND THAT YOU'RE ANGRY,
BUT WE LOVE YOU TOO MUCH TO LET YOU DO THIS!
FRIENDS DON'T LET FRIENDS TAKE INSULIN.
I NEED PARAMEDICS TO COME WITH AN INSULIN SHOT BECAUSE MY
WELL-MEANING FRIENDS DIDN'T KNOW I HAVE DIABETES AND THEY FLUSHED
>>SIR, WE CAN'T HELP YOU IF YOU'RE GOING TO MAKE UP WORDS.
DID YOU LEARN SOMETHING ABOUT DIABETES FROM THAT SKETCH?
IF YOU ANSWERED "NO," YOU NEED TO WATCH THIS THING AGAIN.
GO ON. GIT. YOU THOUGHT YOU WERE JUST HERE TO LAUGH.
